# Sensitivity Analyses: 60%

In the next section we report the sensitivity analyses based on all participants with at least 60% correct responses.

```{r 60%prep, echo = TRUE}
df_analysis21 <- subset(df, df$Surveys.completed >= 21)

#scale independent continuous variables
df_analysis21$StructureForSolitudeIndividualScaled <- scale(df_analysis21$StructureForSolitudeIndividual)
df_analysis21$DayLevelIntentionalitySolitudeScaled <- scale(df_analysis21$DayLevelIntentionalitySolitude)
df_analysis21$DayLevelNatureScaled <- scale(df_analysis21$DayLevelNature)
df_analysis21$DayLevelStructureSolitudeScaled <- scale(df_analysis21$DayLevelStructureSolitude)

df_analysis21$Alone <- as.factor(as.character(df_analysis21$Alone))


df_analysis21_2 <- df_analysis21 %>% select(LowArousalNegativeAffectMean, LowArousalPositiveAffectMean, HighArousalNegativeAffectMean, HighArousalPositiveAffectMean, Alone)
```


## Research Question 1

### Hypothesis 1a
```{r 601a, echo = TRUE}
lme21RQ1d <- lme4::lmer(HighArousalPositiveAffectMean ~ Alone + (1 + Alone | Participant.ID) + (1 | SubjDay), data = df_analysis21) #-> converges

#get first summary
summary(lme21RQ1d)




#check assumptions
#1) Outliers
#proportion of residuals larger than +/- 2, 2.5, 3.
sum(abs(resid(lme21RQ1d , scaled = TRUE)) > 2) / length(resid(lme21RQ1d ))
sum(abs(resid(lme21RQ1d , scaled = TRUE)) > 2.5) / length(resid(lme21RQ1d )) 
sum(abs(resid(lme21RQ1d , scaled = TRUE)) > 3) / length(resid(lme21RQ1d )) 

#2) Homoscedasticity
plot(lme21RQ1d, type = c('p', 'smooth'))
#Looks fine

#3) Normality
#densityplot of the scaled residuals
densityplot(resid(lme21RQ1d, scaled = TRUE))
#qqplot of the scaled residuals
car::qqPlot(resid(lme21RQ1d, scaled = TRUE))

#Normal enough, but the qqplot some outliers in the tails, small problem

RQ1d_p <- afex::mixed (HighArousalPositiveAffectMean ~ Alone + (1 + Alone | Participant.ID) + (1 | SubjDay), data = df_analysis21, type = 3, method = "KR", test_intercept = TRUE, cl = MyCluster)
RQ1d_p
#effect of alone significant
#positive estimate


by(df_analysis21_2,df_analysis21_2$Alone, summary)
#check contrasts to verify results
contrasts(df_analysis21$Alone) 

#Hypothesis 1A confirmed



```

Hypothesis 1a is also confirmed for the 60% sensitivity analyses.

### Hypothesis 1b

```{r 601b, echo = TRUE}
lme21RQ1c <- lme4::lmer(HighArousalNegativeAffectMean ~ Alone + (1 + Alone | Participant.ID) + (1 | SubjDay), data = df_analysis21)

#get first summary
summary(lme21RQ1c)



#check assumptions

#proportion of residuals larger than +/- 2, 2.5, 3.

RQ1c_p
#effect of alone not significant
#Hypothesis 1b not confirmed
```

Hypothesis 1b is not confirmed.

### Hypothesis 1c


### Correction for Multiple Testing

Next we check whether these effects also hold after correction for multiple testing.

```{r 60mt, echo = TRUE}

df_analysis21RQ1_pvalues <- as.data.frame(rbind(RQ1_p$anova_table$`Pr(>F)`, RQ1b_p$anova_table$`Pr(>F)`, RQ1c_p$anova_table$`Pr(>F)`, RQ1d_p$anova_table$`Pr(>F)`))

df_analysis21RQ1_pvalues$adjusted <- p.adjust(df_analysis21RQ1_pvalues$V2, method = "holm")


df_analysis21RQ1_pvalues$adjusted
```

Hypothesis 1a and 1d are confirmed after correction for multiple testing. The effect observed at 1C also remains significant after correction for multiple testing.

## Research Question 2

### Hypotheses 2Aa and 2Bc

```{r 602a, echo = TRUE}
lme21RQ2d <- lme4::lmer(HighArousalPositiveAffectMean ~ Alone*DayLevelNatureScaled + (1 + Alone*DayLevelNatureScaled | Participant.ID) + (1 | SubjDay), data = df_analysis21) #-> does not convergence

lme21RQ2d <- lme4::lmer(HighArousalPositiveAffectMean ~ Alone*DayLevelNatureScaled + (1 + Alone*DayLevelNatureScaled | Participant.ID) + (1 | SubjDay), data = df_analysis21, control = lmerControl(optimizer = "bobyqa")) #does not convergence

lme21RQ2d <- lme4::lmer(HighArousalPositiveAffectMean ~ Alone*DayLevelNatureScaled + (1 + Alone*DayLevelNatureScaled | Participant.ID) + (1 | SubjDay), data = df_analysis21, control = lmerControl(optimizer = "bobyqa", calc.derivs = FALSE)) #-> converges 

#get first summary
summary(lme21RQ2d)



#check assumptions
#1) Outliers
#proportion of residuals larger than +/- 2, 2.5, 3.
sum(abs(resid(lme21RQ2d , scaled = TRUE)) > 2) / length(resid(lme21RQ2d )) 
sum(abs(resid(lme21RQ2d , scaled = TRUE)) > 2.5) / length(resid(lme21RQ2d )) 
sum(abs(resid(lme21RQ2d , scaled = TRUE)) > 3) / length(resid(lme21RQ2d )) 

#2) Homoscedasticity
plot(lme21RQ2d, type = c('p', 'smooth'))
#looks mostly fine

#3) Normality
#densityplot of the scaled residuals
densityplot(resid(lme21RQ2d, scaled = TRUE))
#qqplot of the scaled residuals
car::qqPlot(resid(lme21RQ2d, scaled = TRUE))

#qqplot shows quite some outliers in the tails


#Calculate p-values
#says the predictor is not centered on zero, but like 15 digits after the comma are 0s
RQ2d_p <- afex::mixed(HighArousalPositiveAffectMean ~ Alone*DayLevelNatureScaled + (1 + Alone*DayLevelNatureScaled | Participant.ID) + (1 | SubjDay), data = df_analysis21, control = lmerControl(optimizer = "bobyqa", calc.derivs = FALSE), type = 3, method = "KR",test_intercept = TRUE,  cl = MyCluster)
RQ2d_p 
#2Aa not supported. "Support" for 2Bc/d because we predicted no effect and there is no effect
#Significant effect of Alone
```

Hypothesis 2Aa is not supported. However, as expected, we find no significant interaction effect (2Bc)

## Exploratory Research Questions

### Preparation

Here we prepare the 60% sensitivity analysis of the exploratory research question

```{r RQ560prep, echo = TRUE}

#create lagged alone variable as preparation for creating the epoch variable
df_analysis21 <- 
  df_analysis21 %>%
  group_by(Participant.ID) %>%
  mutate(AloneLagged = dplyr::lag(Alone, n = 1, default = NA))

#create epoch. epoch = 1 if alone & alone lagged are not equal and not NA.
df_analysis21 <- 
  df_analysis21 %>%
  mutate(epoch = ifelse(Alone == 1 & AloneLagged == 0 | Alone == 0 & AloneLagged == 1, 1, 0)) 

df_analysis21$epoch <- as.factor(as.character(df_analysis21$epoch))

#create affect.0 variables, which are the lagged versions of the affect variables.
df_analysis21 <- 
  df_analysis21 %>%
  group_by(Participant.ID) %>%
  mutate(LowArousalNegativeAffectMeanLagged = dplyr::lag(LowArousalNegativeAffectMean, n = 1, default = NA))

df_analysis21 <- 
  df_analysis21 %>%
  group_by(Participant.ID) %>%
  mutate(LowArousalPositiveAffectMeanLagged = dplyr::lag(LowArousalPositiveAffectMean, n = 1, default = NA))

df_analysis21 <- 
  df_analysis21 %>%
  group_by(Participant.ID) %>%
  mutate(HighArousalNegativeAffectMeanLagged = dplyr::lag(HighArousalNegativeAffectMean, n = 1, default = NA))

df_analysis21 <- 
  df_analysis21 %>%
  group_by(Participant.ID) %>%
  mutate(HighArousalPositiveAffectMeanLagged = dplyr::lag(HighArousalPositiveAffectMean, n = 1, default = NA))

#scale the lagged variable as predictor

df_analysis21$LowArousalNegativeAffectMeanLaggedScaled <- scale(df_analysis21$LowArousalNegativeAffectMeanLagged)

df_analysis21$LowArousalPositiveAffectMeanLaggedScaled <- scale(df_analysis21$LowArousalPositiveAffectMeanLagged)

df_analysis21$HighArousalNegativeAffectMeanLaggedScaled <- scale(df_analysis21$HighArousalNegativeAffectMeanLagged)

df_analysis21$HighArousalPositiveAffectMeanLaggedScaled <- scale(df_analysis21$HighArousalPositiveAffectMeanLagged)
```

Next, we perform all four analysis and perform a correction for multiple testing where necessary.

```{r RQ560analysis, echo = TRUE}
df_analysis21 <- 
  df_analysis21 %>%
  group_by(Participant.ID) %>%
  mutate(AloneLagged = dplyr::lag(Alone, n = 1, default = NA))

df_analysis21 <- 
  df_analysis21 %>%
  mutate(epoch = ifelse(Alone == 1 & AloneLagged == 0 | Alone == 0 & AloneLagged == 1, 1, 0))
```

For all four analysis, Alone and the lagged affect variable emerge as significant predictors. Here, we are mainly interested in the effect of the lagged affect variables. Therefore, we correct for multiple testing for the effect of the lagged affect variables

### Correction for Multiple Testing

```{r RQ640mt, echo = TRUE}


#Adjust effect of affect.0 variables
df_analysis21RQ5.2_pvalues <- as.data.frame(rbind(RQ5_p$anova_table$`Pr(>F)`[2], RQ5b_p$anova_table$`Pr(>F)`[2], RQ5c_p$anova_table$`Pr(>F)`[2], RQ5d_p$anova_table$`Pr(>F)`[2]))

df_analysis21RQ5.2_pvalues$adjusted <- p.adjust(df_analysis21RQ5.2_pvalues$V1, method = "holm")
df_analysis21RQ5.2_pvalues$adjusted #all remain significant


```

All four p-values for the effect of the affect.0 variables remain significant even after correction for multiple testing.
